## Using GitHub

For this couse we will store all Python and Bash scripts on GitHub.  This will alllow us to utilize the version control system Git and work from an online repository instead of storing all code on a single device.  In doing so, you will be able to collaborate with others more easily and use multible devices on the same project such as a PC at school, a Mac at home and a Raspberry Pi that travels with you.

<u>Sign up for a GitHub account</u>
Go to <a href="https://github.com/" target ="_blank">GitHub</a> and choose "Sign up".  Create and verify your account.  Be sure to record your credentials somewhere for later.

To understand what GitHub is and how we can use it with any programming language complete <a href="https://guides.github.com/activities/hello-world/" target = "_blank">the Hello World Tutorial</a>.  You should also watch this introductory video as well:

## Controlling the Raspberry Pi Remotely

Using a remote shell, one can control a Raspberry Pi with another computer.  You can do this through the linux command line or with a GUI using a service like Tight VNC.  Learning how to do this will allow our robots to become less tethered to a specific location.  This concept, more broadly is known as the Internet of Things (IoT).  Devices with internet connections can interact with one another over that connection.  Many of you probably already have some IoT devices in your homes like thermostats that interact with each other to maintain the most energy-efficient comfort in your house to security cameras that may be accessed on a mobile device from anywhere.  In short, our robots will not be fully robots until we learn to do this.  As a result, the Capstone project for this course in semester two requires this.

In all cases one thing is assumed.  The Raspberry Pi and the device using the Secure Shell are connected to the same router.  In our lab, we will use the MechLab wifi network.  At home, students will need to make sure to connect the pi to their home router which the computer is using.

This process will work for a computer running Windows, MacOS or Linux.  <b>It will not work for a Chromebook.</b>

### Setting up SSH for Windows

<b>Complete the following steps to create a secure shell connection with a computer running Windows:</b>
<ol>
  <li>Be sure the Raspberry Pi is turned on and connected to router.</li>
  <li>Be sure the computer is connected to the same network.</li>
  <li>Open a terminal window on the Pi and type ```ip address show```.</li>
  You will see something like this:
  
  <li>Make a note of this address, this is the address of the Pi on the network.  The computer will also have an ip address on the network.  To see that address open Windows PowerShell and type ```ipconfig```.  The "IPv4 Address" is the address of the computer.  If both are on the same network, the first three numbers should be the same.  If not, they are not connected to the same network and a SSH connection cannot be made.</li>
  <li>Download and install <a href="https://www.chiark.greenend.org.uk/~sgtatham/putty/latest.html" target=_blank>Putty</a> (Most will choose the 64 bit Windows Installer file).</li>
  <li>Open Putty.</li>
  <li>In the "Host Name (IP address)" box, type in the address of the Raspberry Pi.</li>
  <li>Click "Yes" at the warning.</li>
  <li>Enter the username and password for the device.</li>
</ol>
You are now connected to the Pi via SSH to the command line.

If you would like to set up a graphical user interface (GUI) for use with SSH you can try using <a href="https://www.tightvnc.com/download.php" target ="_blank">TightVNC</a>.  This <a href="https://www.howtogeek.com/141157/how-to-configure-your-raspberry-pi-for-remote-shell-desktop-and-file-transfer/" target ="_blank">HowToGeek Guide</a> shows you how to do it.

### Setting up SSH for Mac or Linux

In case you need to use Mac or Linux for your host computer, the process is very similar for each.  Follow <a href="https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/remote-access/ssh/unix.md" target = "_blank">this guide</a> to set it up.
